Article Title: Juventus 2 - Sampdoria 1: Initial reaction and random observations
Comment Body:
- The game was good, we never really went all out it was in control. I was expecting meh January but it seems our winning streak has given players enough confidence that we are winning without getting out of second gear. Its all good and all but I feel a defeat is around the corner, which will help them push them into form. Hopefully it wont be against a title rival, in cup competition and we recover in time for Bayern game. Allegri has been very agitated lately going apeshit over lil things. Maybe he is under pressure of maintaining the longest winning streak of his career or maybe he too is expecting a defeat soon, no idea what he will do when we lose.
- IDK if it was just me but seeing the team play I had confidence the team will see the match thru and wasnt anxious like vs Carpi barring the period between the cassano goal and fernando shot the team was calm. They didnt lose their shit (maybe thx to Allegri going crazy). There was an air of confidence around them and they just knew they will not be beaten AGAIN. Its much more difficult to maintain that after conceding a goal especially since next one will be equalizer. The last minute play where Rugani shepherd Muriel out for corner and cheillini heading the ball heading for goal was great. My only complaint is they dont manage the possession in the last 5 mins or so well, we had so many chances to maintain possession but they just clear the ball, best example was after the tackle on Zaza which got the samp player sent off rather than keeping the ball playing among themselves or bringing it to the corner flag they just hit long which the samp defence got and the attacked again. Not sure if this Allegri’s instruction or they do it themselves.
- The team is developing very well, we are in cruise control now and they are amazing. When we reach peak we are going to be unplayable, I hope we peak right before Bayern game that will increase odds of winning. Pogba is starting to hit form now if Morata finds his form, pereyra comes back, Asamoah, caceres and khedira can stay fit and hopefully hernanes improves further with continue integration of Rugani we have a truly awesome team. Our rivals is definitely shitting bricks.
- Today’s Rugani was good, he keeps performing like this more and more game time will come towards him, with Barzagli reported out for 1 mth and Games coming thick and fast he and caceres both will get good share of time. Hernanes improved leap and bounds from his previous performance, yes his defensive contribution isnt as great as Marchisio and he is kind of defensive liability but he is more creative, when the team adapts to his style of play we will hv decent back up for Marchisio vs small teams. I really doubt we will get a new regista/CDM/deep lying playmaker in january so till summer he is good option provided this wasnt a fluke game and he can continue to perform AT THE VERY LEAST like this game.
- I hv been saying from preseason our main contender will be Napoli, they are definitely living up to the label tho they seem to be highly dependent on higuain who with Aguero is one of the biggest choker n the game. It remains to be seen whether Sarri has address the issue or like last season and the seasons before it creeps up towards the end of season. We hv advantage over Napoli as the team and the coach knows how to win and are used to the pressure unlike Sarri and Napoli + we have a deeper squad and hv having play 2 games a week from september we are used to it/getting used to it while for Napoli now will be true test as they will hv to field their top team in EL and Seria A no more 2nd team in EL.
- Inter, Fiorentina and MAYBE Roma will be fighting for 3rd spot it depends to be seen which one of them will win, I have a feeling it will be Fiorentina but its too hard to predict, one thing I am sure top two is Juventus and Napoli. YES just like beginning of the season I am very sure we will scudetto.
OT
- On the abv note seeing Berardi play vs Inter it was incredible to watch the understanding he and vrsaljko, if we really bring both of them in summer and hold on to our stars (Pogba, Dybala, Sandro, Zaza/Morata) and add those two I am VERY CERTAIN we will win UCL next season. No, I am not delusional. The current team has great potential which we havent reach yet and hopefully will reach by end of season adding the two missing cogs Vrsaljko and Berardi will allow us to play 4 man back line with a proper RB of Sandro lvl and another playmaker. Berardi has steadily improved over the past two season and is much more a team player, vs Inter it was very interesting to see a young player like him having the excellent off the ball movement which ends up creating a lot of space for sansone and vrsaljko and his passing his sublime. He was everywhere, I am definitely sure now he can play a free roaming SS like dybala so we can play with two SS supporting (one who tends to move center and the other drift wide) a ST. Other additions will depend on who leaves in summer.

Article Title: Juventus 2 - Sampdoria 1: Initial reaction and random observations
Comment Body:
Max has typically been a calm and collected manager. He gives off a mentor/teacher-like vibe. he genuinely cares about his job and his team and players.
There are passionate teachers out there who can produce a serene learning environment conducive to development and building self-confidence in pupils. They can also exhibit tough love to push their students forward and prevent them from getting complacent. To keep good students progressing, you often need to challenge them more and gradually set expectations higher to keep them from stagnating.
In many ways I feel that Allegri does this with his team. I don’t mean this to be a Conte vs Allegri argument, but I would just like to make one observation of the contrast between the two managers’ styles.
Conte’s soldier-like method of constantly being in his players ears on the pitch and training ground rejuvenated (pun intended) this team and gave them a never-die attitude. In doing so for three straight years, it seemed the message, or perhaps more so, the regime worn thin and physically, and mentally exhausted the players and the coach himself.
Allegri, on the other hand, who is much calmer and cool-headed, even under pressure, seems like a manager whose methods could translate into a longer run of success. He exudes a quiet confidence, and although fans and critics may have questioned some of his personnel choices or tactical decisions early on, he always calmly explained his choices in a logical way. He handles the media well, and has a proven track record of nurturing and developing youngsters.
We have recently seen his "wild side" on the touch line with more frequency, considering that this team had to climb from 15th place to only 2 points from top spot. He understand that you can’t keep a team of champions only motivated to winning it all by just keeping things serene. He kept things calm when it seemed like everyone else was giving this team more flak than they deserved.
Now that he has navigated his ship through an early treacherous voyage and weathered the storm, he is sure to keep his team motivated to see this through to the end. We all saw how a few moments of complacency within a match (e.g. Carpi) can potentially derail our progress and undo all the good things this team has done since our loss to Sassuolo. Allegri sees this, and for that reason, he has raised his grinta to more visible and audible levels (insert DBZ meme here). He has that great blend of having a calming effect and being able to flip the switch and tell his players to get their collective head out of their ass when need be.

This side could buzzsaw all the way unscathed to the rematch with Napoli (the one question mark being what side Max fields in the Coppa at the Olimpico). Comment Title: Okay maybe this is time to go on my Morata rant
Comment Body:
I’m getting seriously annoyed about the majority of criticism of Morata as of late, seeing suggestions that he isn’t our future and that he should be our 4th striker and so on and so forth.
I totally agree that right now, at this point in time, Zaza and Mandzu are both in much better form than him, and they should continue to see minutes in the first team until their form goes back down.
What I don’t agree with is that Morata should just be disregarded until we’re in a position of emergency. This guy pretty much singlehandedly got us to the CL final last year because Tevez totally shut down on occasion in the CL last year (not to take anything away from Tevez, I love him and I’m forever grateful for his time at the club). Morata stepped up when he needed to most.
I totally understand the criticism of his game as of late, but it really seems like most of the suggestions are that he’s an inferior striker and we don’t really need him.
It just seems as of late that some people have a very short memory and are pretty much disregarding what he showed he could be last year. Let’s not forget that the guy is only 23 years old! He still needs minutes. He still needs to be part of the picture. He is still a HUGE part of our future if he chooses to be, and I will continue to back him. Because if you’re giving me the keys to Juventus and I need to pick one striker on this team for a 1 game CL final, I’m picking Morata every time, form aside.

Comment Title: I don't think he has the ability. Plus his lack of mobility is scary at times
Comment Body:
His best attributes to me are his ability to move into pockets of space to recieve forward balls, and his ability to make the correct decision once he recieved it there
I think for our team his most important job is to get the team up the field off the ball. He is the recipient of so many marchisio and bonucci long ground passes and he keeps it and distributes in a way that maintains our forward movement
In the few times he’s been tested as regista (just preseason) as well as when midfield positioning leads to him being the farthest back, I found him to be very ineffective in the position.
Sami is a player to me that needs to be able to make runs without the ball. It’s simply his greatest attribute. With his complete lack of any type of pace, if he made one run and we got countered on with him up the field, we’re toast.
At the same time, limiting Sami to staying back takes away his greatest attributes. Also when I’ve seen him there, he seems almost uncomfortable in metronome role on his own.
I hope that makes at least a little sense. I’m at work and kinda rushed my points. I wrote more in depth about my issues with Sami on one of the post game threads from Verona where I was proposing pogba play at regista
I just think he needs a second DM or else we’re gonna get burned. And with the proposed inverted triangle it seems max may be thinking the same

Article Title: Reports: Juventus 'on the verge' of acquiring Cesena midfielder Stefano Sensi
Comment Title: That still creates the wrong movement.
Comment Body:
That still creates the wrong movement for one of them (likely Dybala). With the 4-3-2-1, the TQ’s can basically run forward or drift out – as cutting in puts them into two players almost immediately. So with the LF, Berardi would be able to move from right to left – putting him on his strong foot to shoot. Dybala would be moving from left to right, which puts him on his weak foot. Obviously it’s more fluid than that, but for both players to occupy the quasi-central space forces one of them onto a weak foot when they move out – and they can’t both move in the same direction, or else the’ve just congested the box.
I could see it working with one centrally and one on the right in a 4-3-3, but Morata is my question there. That’s not to say he can’t do it, but I just can’t remember any specific instances in which two inverted wingers worked with a SS. I know Barca tried it for a while with Neymar and Sanchez on the wings and Messi in the middle, but the games were very disconnected and relied on a lot of individual brilliance from the trio rather than spacing and teamwork (or, when it did rely on spacing and teamwork, stalled…a lot).
I’d be interested in seeing if Juve could bring in someone like Mkhitaryan. He can provide width on either side of the formation, which would allow Morata to play both centrally and on the wing, and would keep the 4-3-1-2 open as a possibility. Not saying it should happen, but I’m interested in the idea at least.

Article Title: Reports: Juventus 'on the verge' of acquiring Cesena midfielder Stefano Sensi
Comment Title: Morata is definitely a physical presence.
Comment Body:
I’m not sure if (or how) the physicality on the wings would change things from the physicality in the middle, but it’s definitely an interesting counter. Perhaps there’s another team that’s run a comparable front three with success that I don’t know about, or perhaps it’s an innovative idea that Juve creates.
As for Messi – he did play centrally for a while. Under Pep, though, Barca always had a winger. It’s one of Pep’s core philosophies. The front line always consists of a winger, a CF, and an inverted winger. The only time I can think of that differed was the first trio under Pep. From there it was Villa (inverted winger), Messi (CF), and Pedro (winger on the right side) or Pedro, Messi, Sanchez. When the team did leave that philosophy and run a 4-3-3 with Messi as a CF and two inverted wingers the team stalled a lot. Teams parked the bus against us with a fair amount of ease, the offense relied on the individual brilliance of Messi, Sanchez, or Neymar.
I don’t want to say it was ugly (nothing Messi does is ever really "ugly" and Neymar’s a pretty special talent, too), but it wasn’t pretty. Teams just crammed guys into the box, because none of our wingers were really worth a damn when it came to providing width, and cramming guys into the box separated Messi from the other forwards – and occasionally the midfield. That peaked under Tata Martino – and from there we got another physical CF to create that space.

And when he’s in front of goal, he doesn’t fucking waste it.
Morata is more of a build-up player, he’s more involved in the building up of the attack and you can see him on the sides a lot more, also his finishing isn’t as good as Zaza’s so he misses a lot of his chances.
I wish Morata could learn from Zaza and see the runs he makes and his positioning, he really needs to step those skills up (because it’s vital for a striker).

Article Title: Juventus 3 - Hellas Verona 0: Initial reaction and random observations
Comment Title: One does not get back into form by playing fewer minutes.
Comment Body:
This isn’t a video game where people return to neutral from not playing in matches. Guys need some mental/physical rest to recover from poor form, but Morata’s had plenty of that. At this point it’s about allowing him to play out of his funk. It’s not about reputation, it’s about Morata being the better player with the better skills – and allowing him to get out of whatever funk (unless people believe that his current form is the new standard by which one should judge Morata).
Anyway, I wasn’t saying Morata should or shouldn’t be the third center forward. I just find it odd that people would hope that a guy will choose to stay on their team while simultaneously hoping he plays less. It’s a situation I’ve not seen before. Usually people that are wished to stay are wished to play more and vice versa – I’ve not seen the mixture of the two sides.

Better skills do not always translate into more goal. Sometimes there are strikers that just know how to score, because they know where to be and when to be there. Because they have a strong will. And honestly, Zaza has also a good technique (the two goals against Torino in CI show it pretty clearly). Morata has more talent, but probably less mental strength.
Right now I want Zaza to play more, because he deserves it. At the same time, I don’t want Morata to go. I would like for next year to keep these four forwards: Mandzukic, Dybala, Zaza and Morata. Add in a world class TQ, and we’re set.

Article Title: Juventus 3 - Hellas Verona 0: Initial reaction and random observations
Comment Body:
Just like Zaza worked and waited patiently for his chance, now Morata needs to do the same. Morata is young, he needs to know that coming from the bench doesn’t mean the team doesn’t need him. He needs to learn to have tranquility even when the going gets tough.
There is no real hierarchy or pecking order in Juventus, there is only the preference of the coach for a certain type of player for the tactical setup, and the opposition. Some players, like Marchisio, is capable of being useful in multiple ways, in multiple systems, so he plays. Others, like Padoin, is useful by providing cover in multiple roles. Morata needs to find his place in the team, how he can be useful for the team. Right now, he’s struggling to define his role, partly because of his deployment in the wings early in the season.

Article Title: Juventus vs. Hellas Verona match preview: Time, TV schedule, and how to watch the Serie A
Comment Body:
A must-win game: We’re three points behind Inter, and games after the breaks are always tricky no matter how easy/beatable the opposition is. It will be a great opportunity for Juve to pile some pressure on those in front of us on the table, by the same token it is a chance that shouldn’t be missed by Rugani and Alvaro to showcase their talent and convince Allegri they’re worthy of a spot in the starting 11.
Overall for the rest of the season, I think three things will play a significant role in defining Juve’s season:
1) Alvaro Morata regaining his last year’s form.
2) As good as Evra has been, Alex Sandro’s contribution in the attacking third is far better than his french counterpart. Allegri should start playing Alex in important games.
3) The inevitable return of Juve’s most underrated player—Pereyra. He will be very important, especially in Europe and against plucky defensive provincial teams that love to sit back when they face Juve. Or who knows Juve might get someone good enough to challenge him for a place behind the two strikers.
